conclusion: Determine the maximum width of the incident light beam on the diameter AB of the hemispherical glass brick.
Light beam enters the glass brick from the bottom surface and refracts at the curved upper surface.
Light refracts at the curved surface; angle of incidence α is related to the geometry of the hemisphere.
Using Snell's Law at the curved surface: n_glass sin α = n_air sin θ.
For light to exit, θ must be ≤ 90°; critical condition is θ = 90°, corresponding to critical angle α_c.
Critical angle α_c is given by sin α_c = 1/n_glass.
Light beam enters vertically from below; point of incidence on lower surface determines beam width on AB.
Angle α at curved surface is related to distance d from center O by sin α = d/R.
For light to exit, angle of incidence α must not exceed critical angle α_c.
Substituting sin α = d/R, we get d/R ≤ sin α_c.
Maximum value of d is d_max = R sin α_c.
Substitute sin α_c = 1/n_glass into d_max expression.
Total width of incident light beam on AB is twice d_max.
Maximum width of incident light beam is 2R/n_glass.
Final answer: Maximum width of the incident light beam on AB is 2R/n_glass.
